142.98.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Thank you for having me.

143.98.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Well tell us al little bit, how does one become

147.84.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Well for me it was a rather fortuitous experience.

151.70.text:
I was in medical school, and I was doing some
special research projects, interested in orthopedics

159.00.text:
And the chairman of the department actually
came down to the gross anatomy lab.

162.11.text:
It was a Saturday morning, of course nobody
else was there.

164.93.text:
And I was very impressed because he knew my
name.

169.46.text:
And so, we walked out of the anatomy lab,
we went upstairs, and he walked out of the

173.95.text:
And I was a little puzzled, and I followed
him.

175.01.text:
And he walked to his car and sort of ushers
me to get in.

179.31.text:
And I asked like, "Dr. Watson, where are we
headed?"

182.23.text: He said, "We're going to the zoo."

184.68.text: I thought, oh well, that's really nice.

185.87.text:
I said, "I have some work I really need to
do."

189.56.text:
There was, one of their gorillas had fractured
their hand, and they did not have an orthopedic

194.60.text: surgeon on site at the zoo.

196.68.text:
So, they could do the anesthesia, but couldn't
necessarily do the surgery.

199.56.text:
So, we went over and actually operated on
a gorilla's hand.

202.19.text:
And the interesting part was we put a plate
that we put on one of our forearm bones in

207.19.text:
the bone in his hand to stabilize it, because
obviously he was not going to follow post-op

211.83.text:
instructions, wasn't going to leave a cast
on or anything like that.

214.56.text:
And so, that really opened a door, and the
chairman being a hand surgeon then sort of

219.85.text:
explored that, and that's where I ended up
years later.

222.70.text:
>>Lori Banks:
So, your first patient was a gorilla.

225.01.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Yes, it went very well, so.

227.17.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, so as a hand surgeon, what kinds of

229.54.text: cases or issues are you treating?

231.86.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
We have, I came to practice here, I joined

235.70.text: Dr. Naam, who's also a hand surgeon.

237.31.text: We've subsequently added another hand surgeon.

238.91.text:
And we've limited our practice really to the
hand, wrist, and up to the elbow.

243.63.text:
Our newest partner does some shoulder arthroscopy
and work, but we really concentrate on hand

250.53.text:
There are tendon problems, arthritis problems,
ligament problems, and there's just such a

256.28.text: wide, diverse array of issues that can occur.

259.21.text:
And because of the complexity, we've decided
to really limit our practice to just those

264.67.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Alright, so we're talking today about, we're

266.42.text:
going to getting into all sorts of issues,
but it all kind of falls under a big topic

272.10.text: It makes me sound so smart when I say that.

275.58.text:
Explain what that is and what kinds of issues
fall under that umbrella term.

279.36.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Neuropathy is a generalized term that's used

282.45.text:
to describe nerve dysfunction, so it's not
functioning, acting the way it's supposed

288.47.text:
That can be in the form of loss of sensation,
numbness, tingling.

291.23.text:
It can be in the form of not having as much
strength in that nerve distribution.

296.88.text:
For hand surgeons, the most common compression
neuropathy is referred to as carpal tunnel.

301.42.text:
And that is the median nerve being compressed
in the wrist underneath the transverse carpal

307.55.text:
>>Lori Banks:
I'm going to hold up the hand--

310.16.text:
Explain--
I'm going to hold it while you point out where

312.10.text:
this, where, when you're dealing with carpal
tunnel, where exactly in the hand is that

317.16.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
So, the long blue rubber band here represents

322.77.text:
So, we have two flexor tendons to each of
our fingers usually, sometimes only one to

327.25.text: the small finger, and then one to the thumb.

329.25.text:
Those go through this tunnel, which is right
here.

332.32.text:
The ligament runs from sort of this bony structure
across to these bony structures.

336.94.text:
So, that's the reason that we can get into
trouble is that three sides of the tunnel

342.78.text: Bone doesn't expand really well without breaking.

345.62.text:
And the ligament is sort of a thick, canvas
layer, so it serves as a protective function.

350.83.text:
But if it gets thickened, if it gets increased
pressure, it has limited ability to expand

355.39.text: or bow, and therefore then we develop pressure.

358.46.text:
The tendons deal with pressure a lot better
or more easily than the nerves do.

362.38.text: The nerves are an extension of our brain.

363.94.text: The brain doesn't like increased pressure.

365.82.text:
And when it gets it, then it tells us about
it.

368.33.text:
And most commonly the way it will tell patients
is at night, they may wake up and they may

373.35.text: have some numbness and tingling in their fingers.

376.17.text:
That can occur commonly because of sleeping
position.

378.26.text:
We always talk to patients about if they're
sort of huggers and they crank their wrist

383.52.text:
down, the farther we flex our wrist down,
the more pressure we put on that nerve.

387.38.text:
So, it's one thing to do it for five minutes
while you're doing an activity.

391.08.text:
It's very different thing to do it for two
or three hours while you're sleeping.

393.86.text: And it's often why people wake up.

395.51.text:
Similarly if they have an extended position
in their wrist, they're putting more tension

400.70.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, so we tend to think of people who get

403.34.text:
carpal tunnel, a lot of people who do a lot
of computer work.

Is that the typical culprit or cause of carpal

410.35.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
It actually is not.

412.83.text:
There's a common belief that has occurred,
and they've looked at this over time because

419.97.text:
It's important to know what does and what
doesn't put us at an increased risk.

424.17.text:
And the activities that do are forceful and
repetitive.

427.61.text: So, data entry in and of itself is not forceful.

431.95.text:
Now that we've gotten to the point where most
of the work stations, computer desks are more

438.35.text:
ergonomic, they put our hands in a reasonable
position, that has not been as much of an

443.36.text:
Now I have had a patient, and I'll tell people
that that's my opinion.

446.86.text: Sometimes they don't necessarily like that.

448.82.text:
But and they said, "Well have you ever had
a patient that you said their data entry was?"

452.67.text: And I did, but it was a rather unique situation.

455.10.text:
This was somebody who did monitoring and did
quality assurance in a factory, and they were

459.83.text:
having to monitor parts, and they would have
to enter data.

462.20.text:
Well they happened to keep knocking their
keyboard off out in the factory, and it would

467.23.text:
And their supervisor got upset with that,
didn't want to keep replacing it.

469.99.text:
So, they literally screwed the keyboard to
the wall.

472.76.text:
So, this person had to sit like this--
>>Lori Banks:

476.77.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
And that was not good, and they subsequently

481.43.text:
But running a jackhammer, where you have a
forceful, repetitive activity, but also vibration

489.68.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, so construction jobs and jackhammering,

498.03.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
It's interesting, that was discovered actually

500.54.text:
through primarily the forestry industry and
meatpackers.

505.18.text:
And there's a very, very high incidence, and
it's the cold that adds to it.

510.04.text:
Because, you can take people who do similar
things, but are no necessarily doing it in

515.59.text:
I mean, we're not talking about air conditioning,
obviously, we're talking about cold enough

520.80.text:
And they have a much higher incidence of developing

522.94.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Alright, so what are some of the symptoms

526.82.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Most commonly it will be numbness and tingling.

529.53.text: Everybody, some will say it's a buzzing sensation.

532.94.text: Some say it feels like pins and needles.

534.68.text:
It can then become more annoying or become
burning, what we call dysesthesias.

541.18.text: That usually will happen, again, at night.

543.70.text: But it can happen after prolonged activities.

544.84.text: One of the things is driving.

546.16.text:
Patients will commonly come in and say, "Boy,
I'm driving down the road, I take my hands

549.36.text:
down off the wheel, sort of shake them and
put them back up on the wheel."

553.06.text:
So, a prolonged activity is something where
that'll bring those symptoms out.

557.64.text:
If it gets farther down the road, you can
have problems manipulating small items.

562.61.text:
I'll ask patients or I'll put something on
the desk, and I'll say, "Pick that up."

567.15.text:
And oftentimes if they've gotten to the point
where they're having those difficulties, they'll

570.49.text:
actually take those, scoop them into the other
hand because they can't pick them up with

575.72.text:
They can't put their hand in their pocket
and identify a quarter vs. a nickel because

584.30.text:
Farther down the line most commonly then is
we lose motor, so we lose some strength.

588.58.text:
And for carpal tunnel it's the movement of
the thumb, where what makes this different

592.92.text:
from that gorilla, my first patient, is the
ability to oppose our thumb to bring it out

597.87.text: of the plane of the hand so we can grasp things.

602.19.text: The simians can only do this.

603.60.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Oh, I didn't know that.

604.96.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
So, by our being able to do that involves

607.33.text:
this muscle here, which is innervated by the
carpal tunnel nerve, median nerve.

612.12.text:
And we have some patients that'll come in
that have had it for so long, that that is

616.62.text:
It's completely flat, and they cannot elevate
their thumb.

619.78.text:
That then requires a more complex surgery
to reconstruct that ability doing a tendon

625.67.text:
>>Lori Banks:
So, at what point should someone see their

629.66.text:
And then can you... you obviously don't do
surgery right away.

634.34.text:
But when, let's start with when should someone
see their doctor about this?

637.75.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Well if they're having just nighttime symptoms,

640.66.text:
a reasonable place to start is starting with
just cock-up wrist splints, and that's something

644.51.text: that can be purchased at any one of the pharmacies.

647.93.text:
And it's just designed to hold your wrist
in a neutral position, sort of relatively

652.52.text: straight, maybe a little bit of extension.

654.80.text:
And that prevents you from sleeping in that
funny position.

657.15.text:
If that doesn't resolve it, then you should
be-- because what we don't want to do is sort

661.67.text:
of misdiagnose and let something be farther
down the road.

664.69.text:
Because, there are other things that can cause
numbness and tingling in the hands that we

668.40.text:
don't want to ignore or push down the road,
as far as diagnosis.

671.53.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, so when you do have to go in and do

675.95.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
We're actually releasing that ligament that

679.29.text: goes over the top of the nerve and those tendons.

682.46.text:
And so, I always describe it as this is sort
of a flat-top roof, and what we're doing is

687.73.text: we're going in and releasing that ligament.

689.29.text:
And when there's pressure, when we release
that what happens is that pulls back and elevates.

693.59.text:
By doing that, we've taken the flat-top roof
and we've given it a pitch.

696.56.text:
And so, we've increased the volume of the
tunnel and taken pressure off the nerve.

699.95.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Alright, so where do you do an incision then

703.53.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
For carpal tunnel, if we're doing a standard

705.71.text:
carpal tunnel release, and this is done very
differently depending on your training.

711.09.text:
Years ago people were making an incision,
and it could be an incision from there to

714.53.text: there to release the median nerve.

716.94.text:
As the anatomy and technology has gotten better,
we've been able to shorten that incision.

723.59.text:
So, a standard carpal tunnel incision will
oftentimes be here.

726.63.text:
I do mine endoscopically, so I was trained
from the beginning, so I make a small incision

733.07.text:
I like that from the fact that--
>>Lori Banks:

734.44.text:
I'm trying to show that to the camera, and
my arm just does not bend that way!

739.28.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Because by making an endoscopic incision,

741.88.text:
I don't have an incision on the palm of the
hand.

744.32.text:
If patients are going to have difficulty after
carpal tunnel, most commonly it's tenderness

750.46.text:
I think that's decreased by not having the
incision there.

752.95.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, so a one-centimeter incision sounds

756.86.text:
like a much better deal than a big thing right
here.

759.79.text:
So, what are the, what's the recovery like
if you have that?

763.48.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
For our patients, again this has changed dramatically.

766.07.text:
They used to cast patients or splint them,
and they would be off and not doing anything

771.34.text:
We put them in a soft dressing, so their fingers
are free.

773.44.text: They don't have any splint, they can move.

775.00.text: I tell them use their hand as they're comfortable.

777.04.text:
I said if it's a little bit of discomfort's
okay, you shouldn't be in pain to do anything.

780.93.text:
They're not going to undo what I did at surgery
by releasing it.

784.81.text:
But they can make it sore, they could cause
some additional bruising, so we don't want

788.87.text: them to go out and get crazy.

791.19.text: But a week after surgery we change to a bandaid.

795.40.text: At two weeks we take the one stitch out.

799.03.text: And then I allow patients to progress back.

801.48.text:
Most patients are back to regular activities,
regardless if it's jackhammering or working

805.94.text:
in an office, or taking care of their kids
at four weeks, no restrictions.

810.43.text:
Once you have that surgery, can you get this
carpal tunnel back?

814.83.text:
The published data says five to 10% at 10
years.

817.51.text: I think that personally is high.

819.72.text:
I've been in practice now for over 16 years,
and I'm not redoing five or 10% of my patients,

826.37.text: and I've been doing it for more than 10 years.

828.73.text: So, I think that's a bit high.

830.40.text:
And that's returning back to the activities
that may have put them at that increased risk.

834.60.text: Now the caveat I always tell patients is vibration.

837.89.text:
Vibration will put you at an increased risk,
but it's also something the nerves in general

842.65.text:
And it's the reason that if we run a weed
eater, after a few minutes your nerves are

846.90.text:
like, you know, you feel a little numb because
they're telling you put that down, it's vibrating.

850.23.text:
Well you finish the yard because you have
to, and then you sit down and your hands may

854.38.text: be numb for five or 10 minutes.

857.53.text:
Patients who have had carpal tunnel and vibration
has been a significant component of that,

862.00.text:
if they go back and they have to run a palm
sander or a grinder, or something like that,

865.12.text:
I'll tell them that oftentimes your numbness
and tingling will come back after you use

868.93.text: that implement, and it may last for a day.

871.42.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, it kind of hangs out for a while.

873.55.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Yeah, it doesn't mean that the carpal tunnel

or the pressure is back, but the nerve is
sensitized to that particular aggravating

880.80.text:
And so, I have some patients where they do

But sometime on Saturday the numbness is gone,

But they know because that's their job that
they have to, but their carpal tunnel is not

894.94.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, there was another term that came up

903.46.text:
This is the second most common compression
neuropathy.

905.45.text: And this is of the ulnar nerve.

906.79.text:
So, first it's a different nerve, and it's
obviously in a different place.

911.22.text:
The median nerve, carpal tunnel we were talking
about, can be compressed here.

916.59.text:
The median nerve can also be compressed in
more of the proximal forearm under the muscle.

921.83.text: The ulnar nerve is sort of the opposite.

923.98.text:
The ulnar nerve can be compressed here at
the elbow, at the funny bone as everybody

928.43.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Yes, that's when you hit that and get that

930.50.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Yeah, that sensation is the signal going down

934.06.text:
the nerve, because it's actually the nerve
that you're hitting or contusing that's giving

940.47.text: So, that nerve is at the elbow.

942.75.text:
It can be compressed at the wrist sort of
right next to the carpal tunnel, much less

946.49.text: common for it to be compressed there.

947.98.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, we often hear, you know, carpal tunnel,

952.09.text: We also hear about things like tendinitis.

953.84.text: First of all, what's tendinitis in general?

955.88.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Tendinitis is when you do an activity...

962.46.text:
We go and we lift weights, we get sore because
we've lifted more than the muscle's really

967.27.text: capable of lifting at that point.

969.87.text:
But then we allow them to recover and we're
stronger.

973.41.text:
It's when we overload and we cause some of
that soreness, specifically within a tendon

977.76.text: that we don't have enough time for full recovery.

980.71.text:
And so, it then feeds upon itself and it's
inflammation.

983.80.text:
So, it causes discomfort in movement of that
tendon.

987.50.text:
The most common tendinitis we see are down
in the hands, like in the wrist.

994.95.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
It is called tendinitis, it's more of a tendinosis.

999.08.text:
And it's a fine line, but there's not inflammation,
it's more degeneration.

1003.48.text:
There's more loss of the adherence of that
tendon or ligament to the bone that's become

1010.34.text:
So, for golfer's elbow, tennis elbow, it's
a little bit different.

1013.53.text:
Treated similarly, as far as rest and allowing
for that recovery.

1016.32.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, what kind of activities cause tendinitis

1019.21.text: in the hands and the wrist area that you see?

1021.68.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
It can be repetitive activities.

One of the things that is a common tendinitis

1028.68.text:
there's a sheath that it goes through and
that gets inflamed, we refer to it that way

1032.74.text:

1039.04.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Yes, it can get painful and patients will

1043.01.text:
Now one of the areas that I see it commonly

It's funny because you'll see whether it's
grandma, the new mom, sometimes a nanny or

1054.26.text:
babysitter, because they're grabbing and scooping
the child.

1059.94.text:
And you know, I say to patients, they come

1064.35.text: And she'll look at me, and they just know.

1066.42.text:
And so, that is inflammation around two of

1071.60.text: And it goes through a little compartment.

1073.47.text:
So, our tendons, if we think about them similar

1079.02.text:
in a particular place or they'll want to pull
away.

1082.81.text:
They'll want to go between the two ends of

1084.96.text:
So, if we don't have a sheath, if we don't
have a tunnel for them to go through, they

1090.72.text: So, this it goes through a tunnel.

If that tunnel gets too tight, then it's painful

1097.38.text:
That we can treat conservatively most commonly

1101.82.text:
>>Lori Banks:
So, what kind of, is it an anti-inflammatory

1106.04.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Yeah, it's a steroid, so it is a cousin of

1109.66.text: But the steroids have lots of different effects.

1111.25.text:
People hear steroids and they think, oh my
gosh.

1114.31.text:
One, we're very fortunate in that we're not
injecting it into a muscle and we're not injecting

1118.33.text:
it into a vein, so the body doesn't see all
the medicine.

1122.63.text:
So, people are worried about, and rightfully
so, the effects of steroids when they take

1126.40.text:
them by mouth for a long time or they get
lots of injections in muscles and things.

1129.78.text:
Because, there it's being absorbed and your
whole body is seeing it.

1132.24.text:
In this case there's a limited amount that
your body's seeing, and so we're getting maximum

1135.97.text:
benefit by putting the maximum amount of medicine
where the problem is, and limiting the side

1140.11.text: effects by not being absorbed fully.

1141.83.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, so before you call your local hand surgeon

1145.82.text:
for your tendinitis, are there some things

>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
You can try an anti-inflammatory.

1153.82.text:
I think it's interesting there's new warnings

1160.27.text:
And this sort of came out of the Celebrex,

1165.35.text:
came out that were tolerated very well from
the standpoint of the stomach, but did have

1171.09.text:
Well essentially all the non-steroidal anti-inflammatories
have that risk.

1173.88.text:
You have to be careful because these are over
the counter medications.

1177.80.text:
And I always tell patients if you're going
to take a medication, take it like you mean

1180.54.text:
it, meaning take it at the prescribed dosing
and on the prescribed level.

1188.07.text:
Tylenol's a pain medicine, so if you have
a headache it sort of blocks the pain.

1191.64.text: It doesn't treat the underlying cause.

1193.94.text:
The anti-inflammatories like Aleve and Ibuprofen
are designed to take down inflammation.

1198.54.text:
But for Ibuprofen you have to take it three
times a day, for Aleve you have to take it

1202.62.text:
If you take less than that, then we get the
medicine going up in our bloodstream, inflammation

1206.27.text:
going down, and then as the medicine goes
down we can sort of pinball back and forth.

1209.75.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Yeah, it doesn't really do what it's supposed

1212.94.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Right, and so I tell patients take it for

1214.04.text:
five or six days on a scheduled basis, even
if you feel better after two or three days,

1218.59.text: to really knock that inflammation down.

1221.06.text:
So, I have to ask, are you getting a lot of
people...

1224.56.text:
You know, we're a texting world [makes texting
noise] and video gaming.

1227.90.text:
Are you getting people coming in with issues
with their texting thumbs or, you know, anything

1235.01.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
I think we're seeing more aggravation as far

1236.99.text:
as thumb arthritis because the thumb is also
based on the way it's built and the way it's

1245.92.text:
And so, there's actually an increase in the
amount of weight.

1248.90.text:
So, if we push with one pound of pressure
in our thumb tip, it's three pounds back at

1254.72.text:
That is one of the most common places that
patients can develop arthritis because our

1258.52.text:
thumb does essentially four times the work
of the rest of the hand, because it opposes

1263.57.text:
So, patients, as we get older, my age and
older will start to develop discomfort in

1268.93.text:
the thumb because it's been doing so much
work.

1271.61.text:
But it's also because it's sort of an at-risk
joint.

1274.32.text:
It's a very supple and sloppy joint, from
the standpoint that it can do so many things.

1279.18.text:
It can move in all planes, round and circles,
whereas a lot of our other joints are more

1285.16.text:
They can only sort of move up and down, and
they have limited motion otherwise.

1288.78.text:
By having all that motion, it's a little bit
too sloppy.

1293.03.text:
And so, the bones can slide inappropriately
and wear out to some degree.

1298.06.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Alright, so you had talked about you're seeing

1300.58.text:
something called trigger finger, which isn't
necessarily something that is firing a weapon

1308.80.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
And trigger finger is a condition where the

1312.78.text:
tendons don't want to glide through that tunnel
that we talked about.

1315.55.text:
In this case it's on the palm side of the
hand.

1317.61.text:
So, rather than the top side, we were talking
about De Quervain's, it's on the palm side.

1321.46.text:
And so, they may have either difficulty getting
their hand into a full fist, or if they get

1325.49.text:
it down into a fist all the fingers may come
up at once.

1329.78.text:
Sometimes they actually have to pull it to
pop it loose.

1332.58.text:
Other times they're able to sort of force
it open.

1335.61.text:
That's usually from a little bit of swelling
within one of the tendons, most commonly the

1340.98.text:
We just talked about before we have two tendons
to each of our digits.

1344.97.text:
And if that gets a little bit full, the tendon
and the tunnel have essentially zero tolerance.

1349.97.text: They are perfectly matched as far as size.

1352.18.text:
So, if they get a little swelling, somebody's
not happy.

1356.12.text:
And so, it will have a tendency to not want
to glide as easily, so they have a hard time

1360.36.text:
But if that little bit of swelling gets down,
it gets outside the tunnel, now it doesn't

1364.63.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Oh, so that's where you've got to go [making

1367.07.text: effortful noise], or push it open or in.

1369.30.text:
What's causing that trigger finger, what kinds
of activities?

1371.64.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
It's something that most commonly is idiopathic.

1374.84.text:
A lot of these we have different characteristics
of the person that can put us at increased

1380.80.text:
So, if you're a diabetic you have an increased
risk for developing trigger fingers, different

1387.19.text:
If you have rheumatoid arthritis, that's also
the same.

1390.40.text:
Any kind of autoimmune, inflammatory condition,
so lupus, psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis,

1397.45.text: those all put you at increased risk.

1399.35.text:
Activities, if you are really doing a lot
of repetitive activities.

1403.58.text:
And I think part of the reason, this is again
a little bit of a design defect, but the original

1410.82.text:
[laughing]
It is because of the angle that the tendon

1413.32.text:
has to take as we bend our fingers, because
that first part of that tunnel's right at

1418.36.text:
And so, if you can imagine the tendon is traveling
parallel to your hand, and then also your

1425.23.text:
Well that tendon is taking that 90-degree
turn and can rub on the front side of that.

1430.44.text:
So, if ultimately we have to do a surgery,
all we do is we move that point of transition

1436.07.text:
out about a centimeter to a centimeter-and-a-half,
and it resolves the problem.

1439.15.text:
>>Lori Banks:
Okay, you wanted me to ask you about CMC arthritis.

1442.08.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Yes, that was one of the things I alluded

1445.78.text: to as far as the texting or doing activities.

1447.66.text:
And this little guy has demonstrated lots
of different joint replacements.

1452.18.text:
So, these are all silicone joints that have
been used.

1455.50.text:
But this little cylinder here at the bottom
is one.

1458.81.text:
We don't necessarily use this one anymore,
but this represents the CMC joint.

1463.13.text:
And it's where the thumb comes in contact
with the wrist.

1466.68.text:
And that's the joint that again is at most
risk for those when we are grasping and doing

1471.43.text:
different activities because of the increased
load.

1473.78.text:
And because it's got that variability and
circumduction, moving in a circle, up, down,

1480.43.text: it can slide in and out.

1482.17.text:
And when it does that, it starts to wear inappropriately
on the cartilage.

1486.37.text:
When we have perfectly matched cartilage,
there's less friction between the cartilage

1492.34.text:
than there is between two pieces of ice sliding
across one another.

1495.73.text:
So, when it's healthy and perfect, it is wonderful
When it starts to go south, then we have to

1502.88.text:
>>Lori Banks:
So, is excess of texting or video gaming bad

1509.66.text:
>>Dr. Patrick Stewart:
Because it has a limited load, we're not seeing

1515.62.text:
If you have an underlying problem I think
it can exacerbate or aggravate it, yes.
